sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_aa56c516db4840103b23fa131f9619b5
sys_update_xml.payload:
trueaa56c516db4840103b23fa131f9619b5text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010009 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneWhen job changes happen—whether it’s a shift to a new role, a new department, or a new location—there’sKB00100092019-09-25Assimilating into a new team & job role3a968956db4840103b23fa131f961988kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:53:16global/aa56c516db4840103b23fa131f9619b56admin2019-09-25 18:16:311When job changes happen—whether it’s a shift to a new role, a new department, or a new location—there’s a lot to think about. In your first few days/weeks in a new role, it’s a good idea to focus on understanding your new team and role. That will help you lay the groundwork for long-term success.

Bear in mind that the process of assimilating into a new team and job role can be different for each situation, team, kind of transfer, etc. Maybe you’ll work with your new team only periodically until a replacement for your old role is found, hired, and trained… or maybe, if your new team needs you urgently, you’ll be given significant tasks or responsibilities very quickly.

We know that the lack of clarity can be frustrating. Fortunately, it’s temporary. There are things you can do (see below) to get the information you need to ramp up quickly and thrive.

We’ve highlighted some key points related to assimilating into a new role and team to help you navigate your own situation. We also have an Employee integration planning template that you can use to create your own.

  • Check in with your manager(s) to get their sense of what your assimilation timeline will be. You can mention that you’re requesting this information to help you best manage your time to provide the support they need.
  • Create an assimilation plan of your own. You may want to run it past your manager for feedback. Asking for input from a trusted peer on your new team, or someone in a role similar to your new one, may also be a good idea.
  • While your transfer is in process, start building relationships with your new team. For instance, you might set up 1:1s with your future team members. Find out what people do, what their communication preferences are—and most importantly, get to know them as people. Ask the manager for your new team what you can begin researching or reviewing in advance so you can hit the ground running.
  • Once you’ve begun to work with your new team, watch how those around you work—then try to adopt their style. It shows them that you are committed to fitting in. You may need to “play by their rules” to succeed on their team.
  • Be patient with team dynamics—both within your previous role, and on your new team. Everyone deals with emotions differently, so use your judgment. But keep in mind that if you insist on still spending most of your free time with your old team, it could get in the way of your new team’s interest in helping you integrate.
  • Seek guidance from mentors if you think it will be helpful. If you don’t have anyone you consider a mentor, it’s a good excuse to do some outreach, since having a strong mentor can be a big asset and help you take charge of your career.
]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.payload:
true9ffdcddadb4840103b23fa131f96197ctext6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010013 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneUse this template as a guide to write your own role transition plan. Add, modify or remove sections asKB00100132019-09-25Role transition planning template9652dddadb4840103b23fa131f9619bfkb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 16:44:34global/9ffdcddadb4840103b23fa131f96197c6admin2019-09-25 18:16:322Use this template as a guide to write your own role transition plan. Add, modify or remove sections as needed.

Red text gives instructions for each section; delete once your plan is finalized.

Green text indicates example information; delete and replace with your own details.

Our related articles, Transitioning out of your current role, and Tips for when you’re changing teams or roles, offer more information you may find helpful.

My last day in the position of Senior engineer will be May 31, 2019. The transition plan that follows here outlines:

  • regular duties and responsibilities;
  • upcoming deadlines;
  • outstanding projects; and
  • key contacts.

This document is saved at https://melindasmithroletransitionplan.com, and I will also leave a few hard copies on my desk on my last day.

Regular duties and responsibilities

Summarize your work according to typical routines of your role and/or team.

Use the sections below to group your duties and responsibilities according to whether they are non-recurring or recur daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, or annually.

Non-recurring

Duty or responsibility Success factors
Describe duty or responsibility. Describe how to successfully complete the activity.
Example: Represent our department in recruiting events.Contact recruiter in advance of event to understand the population who will be attending the event, in order to customize messaging.

Daily

Duty or responsibility Success factors
Describe duty or responsibility. Describe how to successfully complete the activity.
Example: Check in with Finance to obtain previous day’s figures for review.Contact Hannah before 8am to expedite the process.

Weekly

Duty or responsibility Success factors
Describe duty or responsibility. Describe how to successfully complete the activity.
Example: Update PowerPoint presentation to include examples from current events.Cite news information from sources that prospective clients already know and trust.

Monthly

Duty or responsibility Success factors
Describe duty or responsibility. Describe how to successfully complete the activity.
Example: Review industry business articles and summarize for team.Write one or two sentences per article; aim to cover about five articles per summary. Send out Tuesday afternoon to increase read rates.

Quarterly

Duty or responsibility Success factors
Describe duty or responsibility. Describe how to successfully complete the activity.
Example: Update team with performance results to identify areas of improvement and strength.Ensure you provide team members with information needed to improve.

Annually

Duty or responsibility Success factors
Describe duty or responsibility. Describe how to successfully complete the activity.
Example: Prepare summary of department’s accomplishments to include in annual report.Contact personnel whose input is needed midway through Q3 so they have enough lead time to write thorough, engaging summaries.

Outstanding projects

Name of projectStatus of projectRelated colleaguesRelevant deadlinesLinks to relevant files
Project name & brief description of project & your roleProject statusInvolved colleagues & their responsibilitiesUpcoming milestonesLinks
Example: Sales Pitch for All-New Product. Create sales presentation introducing our product. Responsibilities include for producing supporting visuals, sourcing data from team and desk research, and ensuring all information is accurate and current.I’m done producing visuals and halfway through gathering current data from technical records. All staff whose input is required have submitted it, except Paul, who has been reminded I need it by the end of June. 

Alia is providing me with technical information.

Taniqua is studying industry reports and summarizing key info. 

Luis will review once a final draft is ready.

Share with internal leadership (i.e. Raphael) by July 15.

Finalize by July 30th.

 

See Sharepoint file entitled All-New Pitch. 

Upcoming deadlines

One-sentence description Completion date Instructions on how to meet deadline
Description Date/Time Notes
Example:Registration deadline for trade show. August 15 at 12 noon.Trade show details available at https://tradeshowlink.com

Key contacts

Name, Title, Organization Contact details Brief description of collaborative work
Name, Title, Organization Email, phone number, contact preferences What you’ve worked on together with this person
Example: John Wilson, Account Executive, Wilson Designs johnwilson@wilsondesigns.com, 555-123-4567Wilson Designs is the industrial design company that builds our hardware. We typically contact them in September to set up the timeline for revisions and new products.

 

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_f2c50516db4840103b23fa131f961912
sys_update_xml.payload:
truef2c50516db4840103b23fa131f961912text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010008 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneWhen you have an upcoming job change, it’s important to create a plan for winding down your existingKB00100082019-09-25Transitioning out of your current role27368d16db4840103b23fa131f9619dckb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:51:42global/f2c50516db4840103b23fa131f9619126admin2019-09-25 18:16:311When you have an upcoming job change, it’s important to create a plan for winding down your existing job—for several reasons.

  • You may be the only person who knows what’s needed to take over your duties or train your replacement.
  • It maintains your reputation with your colleagues.
  • It ties up loose ends. Otherwise, you may find yourself still fielding questions about your former role three months after assuming a new one.
  • It can streamline the process—and sometimes, even plays a part in ensuring the job change actually occurs!

What to expect

  • Different teams and managers approach job transitions in different ways. You may end up working closely with both your current and future manager to develop a transition plan together. Or, you may be largely left alone to write your own plan. Whatever the case, our Transition Planning Template should be useful as a starting point.
  • If your job change involves switching to a new team and/or manager, your current manager and team should still support you on a day-to-day basis; however, job changes often have an emotional impact on teams, and people may make assumptions about why a change was or wasn’t made, for instance. Avoiding lengthy explanations, gossip, or other elements of office politics can help you leave on good terms.
  • If there are any hot issues that could create problems without significant manager involvement, set up a meeting with your current and/or future manager to discuss.
  • You may find yourself performing two roles for some time. If this is the case, communicate proactively with both teams so expectations are clear.

Creating your transition plan

  • Use our related Transition planning template to begin organizing as soon as you learn of your upcoming job change.
  • It’s worth checking with your current manager on how they plan to replace you (e.g., will they hire a new person, split your duties between several people, etc.) so you can format your plan accordingly.
  • If relevant, consider including information about your plans for notifying customers, colleagues and direct reports of the change.
]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_56178d56db4840103b23fa131f961988
sys_update_xml.payload:
true56178d56db4840103b23fa131f961988text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010011 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneUse this template with examples as a guide for planning an employee’s integration into a new team orKB00100112019-09-25Employee integration planning template295d4196db4840103b23fa131f9619efkb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 16:22:41global/56178d56db4840103b23fa131f9619886admin2019-09-25 18:16:312Use this template with examples as a guide for planning an employee’s integration into a new team or role. A manager and employee may collaborate to create it. Or an employee may begin drafting it on their own. For an overview of considerations to keep in mind, visit the related article, Assimilating into a new team and job role.

In the template, red text gives instructions. Green text indicates example information; delete and replace with your own details.

When starting in a new role or joining a new team, it’s also a good idea to start thinking about Setting performance goals and using the performance management system [link to customer’s Performance management tool]. Our related article, Transitioning out of your current role, also offers information you may find helpful.

1. Introduction to people in your department who directly impact/are impacted by you

Meet with the following peers for 30-60 minutes to learn how your job interacts with theirs, what they’re responsible for, and their communication preferences. Determine in your conversations whether it makes sense to meet regularly and if so, schedule meetings.

Peer name Role/Department
Marina Correa Regional Product Manager - Americas
Whitney Young Product Training Manager
Alex MinyakskiTechnical Writer

2. Introduction to people outside your team

Meet with the following individuals for 30 minutes to learn how your job interacts with theirs, what they’re responsible for, and the best way to interact with them.

Key contact Function
Adrian White HR
Jenny BlackWing Commercial Finance
Leeah FranklinTechnical Support

3. Training on software, systems, etc. that are new to you, related to your role or team

Meet with the following people to get access and get trained.

Contact To Learn
Will Brown InVision
Lorenzo LopezSharepoint

4. Familiarization with related teams

Identify the top several teams the employee may interact with, and identify people or informational resources that can be used to become familiar with what they do.

Team People or resources to consult
Regional Marketing The regional marketing department is in charge of creating trade show materials. Review the trade show pamphlets left in binder in top right desk drawer.
Inside SalesThe Inside Sales department must stay up-to-date on product specifications. Schedule a meeting with Penny G. to sync up.

5. Familiarization with office and resources

Identify any areas of the physical or digital work space that the employee will need to know how to navigate.

Tour Rationale
Supplies and print/photocopy equipment Enable the employee to print, scan, & get needed supplies
Campus resources - Gym, cafeteria, outdoor break areasEnable employee to find lunch, work out, etc.

6. Creation of success team with buddy

A success team should have 2-3 members who are one or more levels above the employee and act as mentors and provide performance feedback when requested. One member of the success team should be a buddy — a peer in the same or a related department who agrees to be a general support resource to the employee while they are working through their Integration Plan.

Person Role
Clint Green Team member
Regina Yoo Team member
Ashok PatelBuddy

7. Upcoming events and dates

List upcoming events and dates the employee needs to know.

Event Date
Quarterly sales meeting April/May
Annual regional planning meeting April/May – by phone
Quarterly All Hands meetingJuly/Aug – by phone

8. Meetings to attend

List key meetings the employee should attend.

Department Description
1:1 with Maya (weekly). Set up after orientation is complete. Retail associate status meeting - weekly
1:1 with Karen (weekly. Arrange with Karen, who is taking over Janine’s appointments during Janine’s parental leave.Check with Maya on responsibilities

9. Documents to read

List the documents the employee should become familiar with here, linking out if relevant:

  • Departmental Content Strategy from Fall/Winter 2018 (see https://content.strat.com)
  • Guidelines for Customer Interactions – Version 2.2 (see https://customer.guide.com)
  • Style Guide – See draft copy left on desktop of computer

10. Travel

List any upcoming trips.

Destination/Description Timing
Los Angeles for team sync-up Mid-September – 3 days

Las Vegas for annual convention

Mid-May – 1 week

List expectations:

  • No international travel without prior approval from manager.
  • Corporate credit card only to be used for travel, food, lodging.
  • All receipts to be submitted within 60 days of last travel date.

11. 90-Day deliverables (training, outputs)

Managers need to ensure employees complete appropriate and/or required training. Items should be identified that the new employee will be responsible for completing as they ramp up.

30 days

  • Security training completed
  • Employee handbook read
  • Shared first draft of new landing page with design team

60 days

  • Design thinking training completed
  • Shared second draft of landing page with senior team members
  • Shared first draft of style guide with design team

90 days

  • New landing page design finalized
  • Shared second draft of style guide with senior team members
  • Drafted outline for annual report
]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.payload: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><record_update table="sc_2_kb"><sc_2_kb action="INSERT_OR_UPDATE"><active>true</active><dms_document/><kb_knowledge display_value="KB0010004">9fc3c992db4840103b23fa131f961952</kb_knowledge><name/><order>500</order><question/><sc_cat_item display_value="Promotion Request Form">d1d47d6edbc080105d01f0ec0f9619d3</sc_cat_item><sys_created_by>admin</sys_created_by><sys_created_on>2019-09-25 14:52:22</sys_created_on><sys_id>d842c222db4480105d01f0ec0f961938</sys_id><sys_mod_count>0</sys_mod_count><sys_updated_by>admin</sys_updated_by><sys_updated_on>2019-09-25 14:52:22</sys_updated_on></sc_2_kb></record_update>

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_9fc3c992db4840103b23fa131f961952
sys_update_xml.payload:
true9fc3c992db4840103b23fa131f961952text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010004 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneWhen you are ready to formally inform your employee of their upcoming role change, take a moment to plan.KB00100042019-09-25Communicating to your employee about their job change3434c992db4840103b23fa131f961940kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:42:45global/9fc3c992db4840103b23fa131f9619526admin2019-09-25 18:16:310When you are ready to formally inform your employee of their upcoming role change, take a moment to plan. Advance preparation will ensure you get the details right, of course. But it will also help you take an approach that allows you to positively influence the employee’s feelings about the change.

Use the steps below as a starting point for planning to talk about a job change; you may also be interested in reading a related article, Communicating to employees about organizational change.

  1. Schedule a private meeting to talk in person, or on the phone. Avoid delivering the news by email if possible.
  2. Review the details of the job change the person will want to know—for instance, new position title and supervising manager; date the change will be effective; other major shifts (i.e. salary, location, etc.); and of course, their responsibilities in their new role.
  3. Get information on how the decision to make the change was made and give an estimate of what else will happen in the process of finalizing the change.
  4. Consider the employee: what’s in it for them (if anything; if not, you can be honest about why the change may be necessary, and thank them for their flexibility), and what skills they may have that make them a match for the new role and will help them succeed.
  5. Identify next steps the employee needs to take or what communication they should expect to receive next. They may be interested in reading about how to make a transition plan in our article, Transitioning out of your current role.
  6. Organize notes for the conversation. After covering the information above we suggest asking the employee how they are feeling about the change and listening to any concerns or questions. You can close by repeating next steps or letting them know you are available to answer questions throughout the transition period.
  7. After the conversation, stay in touch. Follow through on any promises you made to obtain further information and demonstrate your continued commitment to their success.

Some other tips:

  • If you don’t agree with the change or why it is being made, avoid siding with the employee over the company. You can say something like, “We might not always make decisions this way in the future, but right now this is how it was done.”
  • Directly acknowledge the emotional impact the news may have.
  • Communicate openly and honestly. Sweet-talk is usually easy to see through, and will probably leave people with a sense they are not taken seriously.
]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_c754c5d2db4840103b23fa131f9619c3
sys_update_xml.payload:
truec754c5d2db4840103b23fa131f9619c3text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010005 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneMergers and acquisitions, re-branding, process updates, and downsizing are just a few of the many kindsKB00100052019-09-25Communicating to employees about organizational change5eb449d2db4840103b23fa131f9619fekb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:45:03global/c754c5d2db4840103b23fa131f9619c35admin2019-09-25 18:16:311Mergers and acquisitions, re-branding, process updates, and downsizing are just a few of the many kinds of organizational change that a company can go through. Regardless of what is changing, employees often feel nervous when they learn a major shift is coming.

And that’s why clear, comprehensive, and transparent communications from management during this time are key. Good communication can foster a sense of preparedness in employees and offset the normal anxiety. Conversely, silence or confusing messages can negatively impact workplace morale and the personal lives of your employees. Below are some tips to help you prepare.

Communicate before, during, and after organizational change.

It’s a sign of respect and courtesy to give people whatever information you have (and are free to share) as soon as it is available. Plus, staying in contact throughout the process can also help you find out about problems quickly (and hopefully address those problems). 

Anticipate employee questions and reach out to address them.

To do this, identify their main fears or worries. Proactive communication shows your concern and professionalism.

Be honest.

If you don’t know the answer to questions that come up, it’s okay to admit it.

Invite feedback and input.

Maintaining open lines of communication fosters goodwill. And allowing people to be involved in the process—by asking for key stakeholder participation—can set the stage for a smooth transition by getting buy-in.

Good luck, and please get in touch if you have any questions or concerns.

]]>General02100-01-01published

Your FAQKB00100152019-09-25Internal mobility FAQ01031512db8840103b23fa131f9619f0kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 16:47:30global/4fe2dddedb4840103b23fa131f9619b05admin2019-09-25 18:16:311Include FAQs related to your internal mobility policy (and internal mobility in general) here.

Your FAQ should address common misperceptions, questions, or concerns—including those related to any confusing or formal terms or language used in the policy.

You can also use the FAQ to support broader HR and organizational goals. For instance, you might include content that highlights your internal mobility policy’s role in creating a workplace that caters to top related concerns of employees (which include transparency around process, access to opportunities for rapid career advancement, and support for diversity).

]]>General02100-01-01published

These guidelines may be referenced during theKB00100062019-09-25Compensation guidelinesd405c116db4840103b23fa131f9619cbkb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:46:17global/b9c4cdd2db4840103b23fa131f9619a05admin2019-09-25 18:16:310Include your organization’s compensation guidelines here. These guidelines may be referenced during the process of determining how employee compensation may be affected by a transfer or promotion.

Note that some companies don’t have compensation guidelines. And at some companies, only senior management has permission to view them.

Also note that HR — including benefits specialists or compensation analysts —are typically involved in compensation decisions. If an employee’s compensation may be affected by their job change, the manager should connect with HR in addition to consulting these guidelines.

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_a445c116db4840103b23fa131f9619ce
sys_update_xml.payload:
truea445c116db4840103b23fa131f9619cetext6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010007 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someonePerformance goals define the results or outcomes an employee is responsible for within a given time period.KB00100072019-09-25Setting performance goals & SMART goal planning templatee4b5c516db4840103b23fa131f961960kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:49:18global/a445c116db4840103b23fa131f9619ce5admin2019-09-25 18:16:312Performance goals define the results or outcomes an employee is responsible for within a given time period. They relate to the core job responsibilities of the role.

Why performance goals matter

Setting performance goals that are right for you and your role can help you focus your energy, organize your time and prioritize your work. Ultimately your goals can help you accomplish the outcomes you desire, and do so in a way that aligns with the company’s mission and goals.

Tracking your progress towards your goals, and studying obstacles that arise and creating plans to overcome them, can allow you to independently take charge of and shape your career. And from a practical standpoint, having clear goals helps you and your manager identify what success looks like so that everyone is on the same page.

How performance goals are used

Performance goals can be tracked using our Performance management tool [link to customer’s performance management system] to capture and document the progress you are making over time.

If your progress isn’t going as expected, you can identify and study roadblocks, and then determine whether a strategy to overcome the roadblock should be put in place—or if perhaps there is a reason the performance goal should be revised instead!

Having data on your progress allows you to cite strong results—using specific numbers—when making the case for a promotion, transfer or raise. You can use your performance data to better understand what your strengths and weaknesses are, then hone your career strategy to best leverage your strengths.

The performance management system lets your manager get updates on your progress; your manager in turn likely uses that information to shape plans and priorities. They also may share information with senior management or leadership, who use it to get a rough snapshot of how all areas of business are doing.

Writing performance goals

Goals should contribute to what the company as a whole is trying to achieve. Typically, performance goals should conform to the “SMART” model (i.e., each goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-Bound). Make sure you revise your goals until they feel right. Pay attention to opportunities to add critical details or to allow the possibility for ideas to remain creative, or evolve.

The template below can be used as a guide to write your own performance goals, and includes sample SMART goals for your reference.

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.payload:
true2db68956db4840103b23fa131f9619d3text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010010 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneInclude your company’s internal mobility policy (sometimes called a talent mobility policy) here. It’sKB00100102019-09-25Internal Mobility Policyabd68d56db4840103b23fa131f961951kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:54:25global/2db68956db4840103b23fa131f9619d35admin2019-09-25 18:16:311Include your company’s internal mobility policy (sometimes called a talent mobility policy) here.

It’s worth taking the time to create a policy outlining your internal mobility program, if your organization hasn’t yet done so. A written policy clarifies how employees can advance and grow professionally while staying within your organization.

The policy confirms that you want employees to advance within your company—and helps them see exactly how to.

A policy may cover topics such as eligibility requirements for internal redeployment, approval criteria, where internal job postings can be found, and the process for requesting a transfer or promotion. However, your organization’s leadership should determine your policy, based on things like the organization’s needs and goals.

]]>General02100-01-01published

${Date}

To: ${subject_person}, ${subject_person_hr_profile.position}

            ${subject_person_hr_profile.address}

            ${subject_person_hr_profile.city} ${subject_person_hr_profile.state}, ${subject_person_hr_profile.zip}

  

RE: Promotion        

 

Dear ${subject_person}, 

 

Congratulations! This letter is to notify you that you have received a promotion. The details of your new position are as follows: effective on ${subject_person_job.job_start_date}, your job title will be ${subject_person_job.position}. You will report to ${subject_person_job.manager}.

 

If you have any questions, please contact ${assigned_to}. We will be providing additional information in the coming days. 

 

Congratulations on your promotion. 

 

Sincerely, 

${subject_person.manager.signature}

]]>Letter of PromotionLettersn_hr_core_document_templateadmin2019-09-25 16:30:16global3e171ea2db8480105d01f0ec0f9619a813admin2019-10-02 17:31:56sn_hr_core_case_talent_management

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_b4921ddedb4840103b23fa131f961941
sys_update_xml.payload:
trueb4921ddedb4840103b23fa131f961941text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010014 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneFor each transfer or promotion of an employee you manage, a lot has to occur behind the scenes. Use theKB00100142019-09-25Manager checklistc8d29112db8840103b23fa131f9619eekb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 16:46:36global/b4921ddedb4840103b23fa131f9619415admin2019-09-25 18:16:310For each transfer or promotion of an employee you manage, a lot has to occur behind the scenes. Use the list below to confirm that you’ve done—or scheduled—everything you need to.

  • Determined, with the new manager if applicable, the effective date for the transfer or promotion
  • Made budget inquiries, ensuring you have funds available for this position or promotion
  • Submitted a job requisition to HR to create a new position or fill a vacant existing position, if needed
  • Communicated with HR to update or write a new description for the position
  • Requested any additional approvals
  • Scheduled a compensation review with HR*
  • Confirmed the job title, working title, job code, location, new manager name, and compensation (if applicable) for the transfer or promotion 

*Item is typically only needed for promotions

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_a2434992db4840103b23fa131f961940
sys_update_xml.payload:
truea2434992db4840103b23fa131f961940text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010003 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneAn employee’s manager typically facilitates a transfer or promotion. A transfer—a change in one’s roleKB00100032019-09-25Transfer & promotion process overview32b38992db4840103b23fa131f96194fkb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:40:42global/a2434992db4840103b23fa131f9619407admin2019-10-04 19:07:290An employee’s manager typically facilitates a transfer or promotion.

A transfer—a change in one’s role within an organization—is a good way for an eligible employee to gain wider and broader experience.

A promotion is a job change that’s typically accompanied by a change in compensation and a title change.

Employees must meet certain requirements to be eligible for transfers and promotions. To review eligibility criteria, consult our Internal Mobility Policy. 

To initiate a transfer or promotion, the manager:

  • Determines the effective date for the change (if the transfer involves a manager change, input from the employee’s new manager will also help determine the effective date).
  • Makes budget inquiries to ensure that funds are available for the position or promotion.
  • Submits a job requisition to HR to create a new position or fill a vacant existing position.
  • Communicates with HR to request creation of a job description for a new position (if necessary).
  • Requests any additional approvals that may be needed.
  • Schedules a compensation review (if applicable).  

To start the process of requesting a transfer or promotion for an employee you manage, use the form at the link below:

Promotion request form

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_83d00112db4840103b23fa131f96199f
sys_update_xml.payload:
true83d00112db4840103b23fa131f96199ftext6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010001 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneInternal mobility refers to transfers, promotions and other job changes within [your company name]. SometimesKB00100012019-09-25Internal Mobility Resources & Info1b624d52db4840103b23fa131f9619a2kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:35:00global/83d00112db4840103b23fa131f96199f6admin2019-09-25 18:16:311Internal mobility refers to transfers, promotions and other job changes within [your company name]. Sometimes also called talent mobility, or internal recruitment, it offers a way for people to learn about different business areas, try out new roles, make lateral moves, advance their careers, and more.

Internal staff mobility is vital to our success as a company. The knowledge and experience of people on our teams got us to where we are today, and it is at the core of our future.

Whether you’re a manager advising employees and initiating transfers and promotions, or you’re an employee preparing for the future, we want to help you understand how internal mobility works. And we want to help you—and people you manage—have long, successful careers with us. That’s why we created this hub of information and resources.

Browse our internal mobility policy, helpful articles, templates, guides and more, below. (Managers: please scroll down to lower portion of page for link to manager-only templates, guidelines, etc.)

Resources & information for all employees

Learn about [your company name]’s official requirements and process for internal mobility

  • Internal Mobility Policy
  • Internal Mobility FAQ

Successfully plan or navigate a transfer or promotion

  • Tips for when you’re changing teams or roles
  • Transfer & promotion process overview
  • Transitioning out of your current role
  • Assimilating into a new team & job role
  • Talking to employees about career growth

Access templates to help you transition out of a role & assimilate into a new one

  • Role transition planning template
  • Employee integration planning template

Measure & track progress to advance your career

  • Setting performance goals & goal planning template

Resources & information for managers

View Manager-only templates, guidelines, and more at Internal Mobility Resources & Info for Managers

Request to promote an employee: submit a request using the Promotion request form [link to request form “Promotion request form”].

Have a question?

If you still need help related to a transfer or promotion, submit a General internal mobility question [link to form “General internal mobility question”]. We’ll get right back to you.

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_ab139512db8840103b23fa131f961951
sys_update_xml.payload:
trueab139512db8840103b23fa131f961951text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010016 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneInternal mobility—that is, transfers, promotions and other job changes within [your company name]—offersKB00100162019-09-25Internal Mobility Resources & Info for Managers15931912db8840103b23fa131f96190bkb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 16:49:58global/ab139512db8840103b23fa131f9619517admin2019-09-25 18:16:131Internal mobility—that is, transfers, promotions and other job changes within [your company name]—offers employees a way to gain expertise in new business areas and roles and advance their careers.

Internal mobility is also vital to our success. The knowledge and experience of the people on our teams not only got us to where we are today; it is also at the core of our future.

We depend on managers to effectively facilitate internal mobility and to strive to support it by offering the right guidance, resources, tools and advice to their teams. Our hope is that with the resources and information we provide here, we’re helping the transfer and promotion process go more smoothly for you—and, just as importantly, equipping you to foster a culture of internal talent promotion throughout the organization.

Browse the topics below to get started.

Promote an employee

  • Promotion request form

Send emails & official communications that are consistent & complete

Prepare for important conversations

  • Communicating to employees about organizational change

Review our guidelines on employee salary ranges

  • Compensation guidelines

Access

  • Our Internal Mobility Policy
  • Articles on navigating and planning for a transfer or promotion
  • Role transition and employee integration plan templates
  • Performance goal setting info & templates

...through the main internal mobility article, Internal Mobility Resources & Info

 

Still need help related to a transfer or promotion? Submit a question through our General internal mobility question [link to form “General internal mobility question”] form.

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_a0ad85dadb4840103b23fa131f96198b
sys_update_xml.payload:
truea0ad85dadb4840103b23fa131f96198btext6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010012 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneWhile a transfer or promotion is in the process of being completed, you may encounter some gray areasKB00100122019-09-25Tips for when you're changing teams or rolesd8dd89dadb4840103b23fa131f9619c0kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 16:24:47global/a0ad85dadb4840103b23fa131f96198b5admin2019-09-25 18:16:310While a transfer or promotion is in the process of being completed, you may encounter some gray areas on topics ranging from vacation requests, to pay and benefits, to workplace politics, to staffing, and more.

A good rule of thumb for this time period is, “When in doubt, ask HR.” We care about helping you get up to speed and have a smooth transition. And we understand that while the transition is in process, you may have more questions than usual. We’re here to help minimize the disruption your role change creates for you and your team.

While a transfer or promotion is pending, it’s possible you’ll be asked to join a project that you may not be able to see through to completion. The person who invites you onto the project, of course, may not know about your pending transfer or promotion. And it is often in the best interest of team dynamics for the change to remain confidential until it occurs. There’s no one-size-fits-all answer for what to do in a situation like this. One option is to check in with your current manager on what to do. Another is to simply get started on the work anyway, knowing you’ll leave with a intact reputation and you’ve set up your team and replacement to succeed.

It’s also possible you’ll be uncertain about whom to ask when you want to do something as simple as request leave. HR can tell you how to proceed; they may handle things for you, or they may tell you which manager you’ll need to coordinate with.

Finally, you may have questions regarding how your transfer or promotion will affect your compensation, and when anticipated changes will come into effect. For instance, if you’re up for a bonus but then transferred to a different team or role before the date when bonuses are distributed, you may wonder if you’re still eligible for the bonus (or a pro-rated portion). Or if your transfer will change what benefits you’re eligible for, you may have questions about timing—especially if you have a limited time window in which to sign up for changes.

Our advice? If you can, sit down and brainstorm all the questions you may have about logistics of your transfer or promotion. Whatever you can’t figure out on your own, check with HR, in a meeting or via email. If you choose the latter approach, however, be sure to allow HR some time to get back to you so that you have the information you need before any deadlines.

This doesn’t begin to cover all possible questions that may arise for you. But we hope it gives you a sense that it’s normal it is to feel a bit uncertain, and to reach out for help, during this time.

]]>General02100-01-01published

sys_update_xml.name: kb_knowledge_72a2cd52db4840103b23fa131f961915
sys_update_xml.payload:
true72a2cd52db4840103b23fa131f961915text6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441falsefalsefalsefalseKB0010002 v1.0false28218512db4840103b23fa131f9619f4bb0370019f22120047a2d126c42e7073truetalent mobility, in-company mobility, internal recruitment, internal sourcing, filling positions internally, hiring internal candidates, internal promotion, promotion, moving to a new team, switching jobs at my company, get a promotion, how to promote, how to get promoted, internal staff mobility, promote an employee, promote someoneFor employees looking to make the most of their careers, some advice is listed below. Employees may alsoKB00100022019-09-25Talking to employees about career growth2f238192db4840103b23fa131f961955kb_knowledgeadmin2019-09-24 15:38:18global/72a2cd52db4840103b23fa131f9619156admin2019-09-25 18:16:310For employees looking to make the most of their careers, some advice is listed below. Employees may also wish to do a general search online for role- and industry-specific career resources.

Research where you want to go, then make a plan to get there.

Gather information on realistic opportunities in your company within your current or desired field—check your company career page [link to customer’s career page] for ideas. Or, view our organizational chart to better understand possible roles that aren’t currently hiring.

If you’re thinking of transitioning to a different discipline, interview people in that area to understand what skills and experience would be needed. Once you’ve done that research, set out goals to help you develop the needed skills and background, and consider reaching out to your manager or mentor for advice.

Our performance management system [link to customer’s performance management system] and our article, Setting performance goals & SMART goal planning template may both be helpful.

Document your successes.

Measure your work and any skills you’ve added or improved on. Whatever you accomplished, note it down somewhere. Assess your progress periodically. Pay attention to any positive changes you’ve observed and try to maintain or improve your degree of improvement.

Some improvements that companies are especially interested in are ones that help increase revenue or improve effectiveness. But work that improves company culture or strengthens your team can also help you stand out—just find a way to measure it, if you can.

Increase your responsibility.

It’s often advised that employees who want to move up the ranks should step up when an opportunity comes their way, even if it’s not a move they’d expected. This way, you can show your willingness to pitch in to help the team, and demonstrate your abilities in as a leader.

Be a standout in your discipline or specialty.

Study the people who are the best in the field that you’re in or would like to move into: read relevant books or magazines, or attend events or seminars, to improve current skills or gain new ones. Sometimes companies will reimburse for education if it’s related to your work for them.

]]>General02100-01-01published
